Histopathology report: Lung: Serous pulmonary oedema moderate acute diffuse. Spleen: Red pulp depletion severe. Liver: Sublethal hydropic hepatosis mild to moderate acute. No signficant changes observed in kidney and heart.
Histopathology comments: As suggested in the history - consider protein-energy malnutrition in this case as possible cause of death. Red pulp depletion of the spleen suggests terminal hypovolaemia (dehydration?).

Histopathology report: Lung: Serous pulmonary oedema and mononuclear leukostasis moderate. Spleen: Lymphoid hyperplasia with terminal follicular lympholysis moderate. Intestine: Subserosal lymphocytosis multifocal chronic; Scattered large coccidial oocysts (benign spp.?) in villous tips. No signficant changes observed in kidney liver and heart.
Histopathology comments: Unfortunately the intestinal specimens were moderately putrefied which affected interpretation. However the pulmonary change is commonly observed with bacterial endotoxaemia usually of intestinal origin.

Histopathology report: No significant histopathological changes found in spleen kidney liver and heart. Marked bacterial putrefaction of the intestines.
Histopathology comments: The history is indicative of possible dehydration perhaps due to mismothering?. No histological evidence of disease could be demonstrated.

Histopathology report: Kidney liver lung and spleen: Severe multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). High prevelence of erythrocytic piroplasms throughout organs. No significant histopathological changes in: Thymus
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever.

Post mortem comments: Virology negative E.coli or salmonella most likely need to type (negative for salmonella)
Histopathology report: Spleen: Severe reticulo-endotheleial and follicular white pulp hyperplasia. Liver: Multifocal random lytic hepatocellular necrosis. Kidney - Mild intersitial lymphoplasmactyic nephritis. Lung - Mild interstitial penumonia mononuclear. Heart - 2+ Sarcocystis infection
Histopathology comments: Consider IMP for Rift Valley fever virus.

Histopathology report: Lung: Interstitial pneumonia serofibrinous moderate acute diffuse. Lymph node: Marked lymphoid depletion and lymphoedema. Spleen: Red pulp depletion severe. Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy severe. Heart: No significant histopathological changes.
Histopathology aetiological diagnosis: No histological diagnosis possible - see comments
Histopathology comments: Trypanosomosis (see smear investigation for Tryp. Spp.) resulting in poor condition (proteien-energy-malnutrition) general immune suppression and anaemia should be considered.The lung change indicates non-specific terminal alveolar inflammation of haematogenous origin. Consider viral (PI3/ BRSV) / protozoal (eg. heartwater) aetiology. NOTE: Histological diagnosis is dependant on complete and accurate sampling at necropsy.

Histopathology report: Intestine: Proprial oedema eosinophilia and lymphocytosis moderate. Lung: Interstitial mononuclear pneumonia mild diffuse. Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy moderate diffuse. Skeletal muscle and heart: Marked Sarcocystis sp. infection. No significant histopathological changes found in spleen and kidney.
Histopathology comments: The intestinal changes are indicative of heavy endoparasitic load. Hepatic atrophy indicates poor nutritional state. Clin. Path report indicates low Hct. indicative of fatal anaemia. The cause for anaemia could not be demonstrated histologically - consider parasitic aetiology.

Post mortem comments: Suspect BVD. BVD negative on ELISA and immunohistochem
Histopathology report: Intestine (ileum) - Clostridial colonisation of mucosae (post mortal?). mucosal prolapse into GALT.No significant changes in: heart liver kidney spleen lung and brain
Histopathology comments: Freezing artefact made interpretation nearly impossible. However no obvious sign of histopathological diagnosable conditions. Freezing of tissues should be avoided. Mucosal prolapse into GALT may be indicative of BVD - mucosal disease. Consider IMP for BVD.

Post mortem comments: Possible chronic ECF or T taurotragi
Histopathology report: Kidney liver lung heart and spleen: Severe multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies).Spleen: Marked erythrophagocytosis. Liver: Severe canalicular cholestasis
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Extravascular haemolysis due to theilerial piroplasm containing eryhtrophagocytosis in the spleen was prominent.

Post mortem comments: No salmonella cultured but sample in very poor condition
Histopathology report: Severe freeze artefact present in all submitted organs. No significant histopathological changes observed in liver kidney lung spleen and heart
Histopathology comments: Freeze artefact made interpretation difficult to impossible

Post mortem comments: Acute foreign body pneumonia probably in response to earlier clinical episode of unknown origin
Histopathology report: Lung - Generalised alveolar exudation of fibrin and protein rich oedema associated with multifocal haemorrhage and pale basophilic amorphous foreign substrate. Multifocal colonies of small bacterial rods were also present - most likely introduced with foreign substrate.No significant histopathological changes in: heart liver kidney and spleen
Histopathology aetiological diagnosis: Fatal fibrinohaemorrhagic pneumonia - suspected aspiration pneumonia
Histopathology comments: Consider dosing pneumonia or aspiration of milk from hand rearing / force feeding. No intestine was submitted examination - coccidiosis as cause for disease state can not be rule out.

Histopathology report: Heart: 4+ Sarcocystis sp. Brain: Glial oedema (cytogenic) moderate. Lung: Interstitial pneumonia mononuclear moderate acute with numerous eosinophils widely distributed. Spleen: Red pulp depletion severe with follicular lymphoid hyperplasia and eosinophil proliferation. No significant histopathological changes in the kidney and liver.
Histopathology comments: The prominent eosinophil reaction could be indicative of systemic allergic reaction or indicative of heavy parasitic infection. The cerebral oedema was non-specific (not typical for heartwater). Heavy Sarcocystis infection is ofconcern and have been implicated to cause disease but is ussually apathogenic

Histopathology comments: No report

Histopathology report: Lung spleen kidney heart: Moderate interstitial infiltration of blast transformed lymphocytes with scant cytoplasmic theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). Liver:Portal lymphocytosis severe with perimortal periacinar hepatocellular coagulative necrosis.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Consider protracted perimortal hypoxia due to pulmonary failure (oedema) resulting in periacinar hepatic necrosis.

Histopathology report: lung: Interstitial pneumonia serofibrinous with scant infiltration of lymphoblastoid cells which contain cytoplasmic theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). only lung submitted for examination
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Submission of a wide variety of organs help to support diagnoses and rule out other possibilities.

Post mortem comments: Bacteriology Staph spp. Positive from lung
Histopathology report: Kidney: Multifocal lymphocytic interstitial lymphocytic nephritis. Lymph node: Follicular lymphoid hyperplasia severe. No other organs submitted for examination.
Histopathology comments: Theileriosis can be ruled out

Post mortem comments: Bacterilogy Staph intermedia (but concern contamination). P104 negative

Kidney - Mild multifocal lymphoplasmacytic perivascular infiltration ant the cortico-medullary junction. Heart thymus liver: No significant histopathological changes.

Kidney: No significant histopathological changes. Post mortal clostridial invasion and autolysis moderate.

Histopathology report: Lung - Intersitital pneumonia serofibrinous with syncytia formation. Skin - Dermatophytosis severe. PAS: POSITIVE fungal hyphae. Brain - Vasculogenic oedema. IMP for E. ruminantium: POSITIVE. No significant changes in: heart liver kidney spleen
Histopathology comments: Consider causes for immunosuppression as contributing / predisposing factors in this case. The lung changes were typical for viral aetiology but E.ruminantium may also responsible. Consider future fresh sampling for pneumoviral PCR assays.

Histopathology report: Lymph node: Lymphoid depletion severe generalised. Lung: Marked alveolar congestion and mild oedema. Spleen: Haemosiderin accumulation in macrophages severe with generalised lymphoid depletion. No significant histopathological findings in Liver kidney brain and heart
Histopathology comments: Splenic haemosiderin accumulation indicates a recent or continuous lowgrade systemic haemolytic event. Consider trypanosomosis. High dietary iron could also result in this finding. Depleted lymphoid tissues could be indicative of poor nutritional or immunosuppressive state.

Post mortem comments: Died over Xmas break early Jan; Staring coat anorexia and nasal discharge for 3 days reported retrospectively by farmer to ST Positive for A bovis and T mutans but negative P104
Histopathology report: No report

Histopathology report: Kidney liver spleen lung and heart: Multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). Heart - 3+ Sarcocystis infection. Liver - Hepatocellular atrophy moderate to severe.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. The changes appeared acute NOT chronic.

Post mortem comments: IBR positive. Was positive for T parva on RLB and P104
Histopathology report: Lung - Moderate interstitial pneumonia mononuclear with focal peribronchial . alveolar syncitial cell formation and macrophage infiltration. Spleen liver and kidney - No significant histopathological changes observed
Histopathology comments: Consider PI3 and BRSV. Although not typical BVD and IBR should also be ruled out.

Histopathology report: Liver: Global periacinar to midzonal acute hepatocellular coagulative necrosis severe associated with mild portal bile duct hyperplasia and severe periportal scattered hepatocellular karyomegally. Heart: 3+ Sarcocytis sp. infection. Spleen and lung: No significant histopathological changes observed
Histopathology comments: The hepatic lesions were typical for changes expected for pirrolizidine alkaloid poisoning and to a lesser extent aflatoxicosis.

Histopathology report: Kidney: Mild interstitial lymphocytic nephritis multifocal. Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy moderate with multifocal mild lymphocytic granulomata. Lymph node: Lymphoid hyperplasia moderate. Lung: no significant histopathological changes.
Histopathology comments: The renal change is non-specific but could be indicative of chronic circulating antigen eg. trypanosoma past bacteraemia. The lymph node reaction was normal hyperplasia to exposed antigen (the origin may indicate the probable cause eg. parasites). The liver finding indicates poor nutritional state.

Histopathology report: Brain:Vasculogenic oedema moderate generalised. Close examination of cerebral capillaries revealed scattered cytoplasmic protozoal colonies in endothelial cell typical for Ehrlichia ruminantium. Lung: Multifocal bacterial microabscessastion mild subacute. Liver: Hepatosis periacinar sublethal non-specific acute mild.
Histopathology comments: Moderate tissue autolysis and putretaction made interpretation difficult. IMP can be performed to confirm heartwater but in my opinion it would be of academic interrest.

Post mortem comments: Early T parva episode which was not called a clincial episode
Histopathology report: Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy moderate to severe. Kidney: No significant histopathological findings. Heart: 3+ Sarcocystis sp.
Histopathology comments: The liver change is suggestive of poor nutritional state possibly cachexia.

Post mortem comments: Trauma presumed dog bite. MCF positive by PCR
Histopathology report: Kidney:Juxtamedullary and multifocal interstitial perivascular lymphocytosis. Liver: multifocal random and portal lymphocytosis mild. Lung: Moderate to severe protein-rich alveolar oedema. Heart: Multifocal subendocardial lymphocytosis mild; 1+ Sarcocystis sp. infection. Spleen: Follicular lymphoid hyperplasia moderate to severe. No significant histopathological chnages in: skeletal muscle intestine and thymus
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. The samples were in moderate state of putrefaction and autolysis which made interpretation difficult. Acid hematin pigment from the use of unbufferred formalin also affected examination. No definite theilerial schizonts could be identified - however the multiorgan lymphocytosis is typical - also consider malignant catarrhal fever and trypanosomosis. The lesions observed were not typical of any kind of snake bite.

Histopathology report: Kidney: Cortical interstitial fibrosis glomerular sclerosis and lymphocytic nephritis multifocal to confluent chronic severe widespread. Spleen: follicular lymphoid hyperplasia moderate with haemosiderin accumulation. Liver: hepatocellular atrophy mild to moderate. Lung: Alveolar oedema moderate with mild terminal neutrophilic leukostasis. Heart: 1+ Sarcocystis infection
Histopathology aetiological diagnosis: Significant renal cortical fibrosis - suspected chronic renal failure
Histopathology comments: No indication of clinical theileriosis could be confirmed. Due to the chronic nature of the disease it would be difficult at this stage to determine aetiology of the renal lesion. The haemosiderin accumulation may indicate haemolysis typical for haemoprotozoa - consider recent trypanosomosis babesiosis anaplasmosis etc.

Post mortem comments: IMP negative so E ruminatum negative
Histopathology report: Kidney liver lung and spleen: Multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis. No convincing theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies) observed. Lung: Alveolar to intestitial oedema moderate with marked capillary mononuclear leukostasis (no theielria schizonts seen). No significant histopathological changes in heartmuscle.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. If the animal was treated it can explain why schizonts were difficult to demonstrate in this case. However also consider trypanosomosis and heartwater (IMP for the latter could exclude this possibility).

Histopathology report: Liver: Multifocal-random acute hepatocellular coagulative necrosis moderate. Spleen: Random-multifocal reticular-macrophage lysis acute with redpulp depletion. Heart: Generalised interstitial oedema moderate; 3+ Sarcocytis sp. infection Lung: Interstitial pneumonia mononuclear moderate with moderate protein-poor alveolar oedema. Kidney: No significant histopathological changes observed
Histopathology comments: Consider Rift valley fever and wesselsbron viral infection. Consider IMP for definitive diagnosis.

Liver: Portal lymphocytosis moderate. Spleen: Follicular lymphoid hyperplasia severe. Kidney and heart: No significant histopathological changes observed
Histopathology comments: The histological changes were typical for partial immunity or tetracycline treated case resulting in protracted disease.

Histopathology report: Lung:Alveolar oedema and moderate capiallary monocytic leukostasis associated with erythrophagocytosis. Babesia sp. observed in many RBC's. No significant histopathological changes in the kidney.
Histopathology aetiological diagnosis: Suspected complicated babesiosis - Pulmonary failure (severe oedema)

Histopathology report: Kidney liver spleen lung and heart: Multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). Liver: Generalised hepatocellular atrophy severe. Spleen: Marked haemosiderin accumulation due to extensive erythrophagocytosis (theilerial piorplasm induced?)
Histopathology aetiological diagnosis: Theileriosis associated with marked anaemia and protein-energy-malnutrition
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Hepatic atrophy is indicative of poor nutritional state (cachexia). This may a predisposing factor resulting in poor immunity to tick borne disease.

Histopathology report: Kidney liver spleen lung and heart: Multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain cytoplasmic theilerial schizonts (koch's bodies). Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy moderate.Spleen: Moderate haemosiderin accumulation usually indicative of haemolytic syndrome or high dietary iron.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Theileriosis in this case may have been a secondary comlication of trypanosomiasis (see smear investigation for Tryp. Spp.) resulting in poor condition and general immune suppression.

Histopathology report: Lung: Interstitial pneumonia monocytic with moderate septal oedema and and alveolar congestion. Lymph node (origin?): Lymphoid hyperplasia and lymphoedema severe diffuse. Spleen: Lymphoid hyperplasia moderate with erythrophagocytosis mild. Liver: Portal fibrosis and bilduct proliferation mild susp. Parasitic. Kidney: juxtacortical perivascular mononuclear leukocyte infiltration mild.
Histopathology comments: Although no Ehrlichia colonies were observed pulmonary changes were suggestive. Consider IMP for Ehrlichia ruminantium.

Histopathology report: Kidney liver lymph node spleen and lung: Multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis some of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies). Kidney: Glomerular endothelial nuclear viral inclusions suspected Adenovirus/ Herpes virus. Liver: Multifocal random hepatocellular coagulative necrosis associated with scant scattered large amphophilic nuclear viral inclusions suspected Adenovirus/Herpes virus. No significant changes observed in myocardial tissue
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Electronmicroscopy may be helpful in determining the viral component in this case.

Histopathology report: Kidney liver lung heart and spleen: Mild multi-organ interstitial lymphoblastosis many of which contain theilerial schizonts (Koch's bodies).
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever.

Histopathology report: Kidney and lung: Mild interstitial lymphoblastosis with scant suspected theilerial Schizont (Koch's bodies) containing lymphoblasts. Liver: Mild portal lympocytosis. Lung: Interstitial pneumonia mononuclear (mainly blas transformed lymphocytes) moderate acute diffuse. Spleen: Follicular lymphoblastosis moderate with marked erythrophagocytosis.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever.

Post mortem comments: Possible Theileria as well but not clear it contributed to death
Histopathology report: Lung: Serofibrinous interstitial pneumonia moderate diffuse acute. Liver: Multifocal portal lymphocytosis mild to moderate parasitic? Lymph node: Marked lymphoid depletion and lymphoedema. No significant histological findings in the heart kidneyand spleen. Intestine could not be interpreted due to advanced putrefaction.NOTE: Advanced autolysis and putrefaction with extensive acid hematin pigment artefact made interpretation very difficult.
Histopathology comments: Pulmonary change is non-specific - consider injurous agent of haematogenous origin eg. bacterial toxins pneumotropic virusses etc. No clear theilerial schizonts could be demonstrated.

Post mortem comments: Viral pneumonina predisposed to bacterial bronchopneumonia possibly predisposed to all this by ECF?
Histopathology report: Kidney spleen lung: Mild interstitial lymphoblastosis with scant theilerial schizont (Koch's bodies) containing lymphoblasts. Liver: Generalised hepatocellular atrophy severe and mild portal lympocytosis. Lung:Broncho-interstitial pneumonia fibrinopurulent severe multifocal to coalescing subacute bacterial. Syncitial cell formation in peripheral alveoli was prominent.
Histopathology comments: PCR is indicated to determine the Theileria sp. involved. Consider East-Coast fever. Hepatic atrophy is indicative of poor nutritional state (cachexia). This may a predisposing factor resulting in poor immunity to tick borne disease. Certain pulmonary chnages were indicative of underlying viral pneumonia predisposing to bacterial invasion. This finding may also relate to poor immunity caused by poor condition and/or theilerial infection.

Post mortem comments: Negative for salmonella. Cultured enterococcus spp.
Histopathology report: Spleen: Marked infiltration of degenerate neutrophils in the marginal sinus of all lymphoid follicles. Lung: Degenerate neutrophilic capillary leukostasis moderate to severe. Liver: Hepatocellular atrophy severe. Kidney and heart: No significant histopathological changes.
Histopathology comments: The changes observed in the lung and spleen are consistent with terminale bacterial sepsis / toxaemia. The origin could not be demonstrated. Bacterial culture is indicated. It is unfortunate that no intestinal samples were submitted esp. with an animal showing diarrhoea. Theileriosis ruled out.
